; <L>28747<pc>165,1<k1>iti
102392 old <div n="p"/><s>i/ti</s> may form an adverbial compound with the name of an author (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>i/ti-pARini</s>, thus according to <s1 slp1="pARini">Pāṇini</s1>). It may also express the act of calling attention (lo! behold!) It may have some other significations <ab>e.g.</ab> something additional (as in <s>i/tyAdi</s>, et caetera), order, arrangement specific or distinctive, and identity. It is used by native commentators after quoting a rule to express ‘according to such a rule’ (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>anudAttaNita i/ty Atmanepadam Bavati</s>, according to the rule of <s1 slp1="pARini">Pāṇini</s1>, <ls n="Pāṇ.">i, 3, 12</ls>, the <s1 slp1="Atmane-pada">Ātmane-pada</s1> takes place). 
;

; <L>28801.2<pc>165,2<k1>idam
102617 old ¦ (opposed to <s>adas</s> <ab>e.g.</ab> <s>ayaM lokaH</s> or <s>idaM viSvam</s> or <s>idaM sarvam</s>, this earthly world, this universe; <s>ayam agniH</s>, this fire which burns on the earth; but <s>asAv agniH</s>, that fire in the sky, <ab>i.e.</ab> the lightning: so also <s>idam</s> or <s>iyam</s> alone sometimes signifies ‘this earth’; <s>ime smaH</s>, here we are.) <s>idam</s> often refers to something immediately following, whereas <s>etad</s> points to what precedes (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>SrutvE<srs/>tad idam UcuH</s>, having heard that they said this). <s>idam</s> occurs connected with <s>yad</s>, <s>tad</s>, <s>etad</s>, <s>kim</s>, and a personal pronoun, partly to point out anything more distinctly and emphatically, partly pleonastically (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>tad idaM vAkyam</s>, this speech here following <pb n="165,3"/>; <s>so 'yaM vidUzakaH</s>, this <s1 slp1="vidUzaka">Vidūṣaka</s1> here). 
;

114046 old ¦ in those rare cases, in which it appears in the <s1 slp1="veda">Veda</s1> uncompounded with a verb, the latter has to be supplied from the context (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>u/d u/tsam Sata/DAram</s>, <ls>AV. iii, 24, 4</ls>, out (pour) a fountain of a hundred streams). <s>ud</s> is sometimes repeated in the <s1 slp1="veda">Veda</s1> to fill out the verse, <ls>Pāṇ. viii, 1, 6</ls> (<s>kiM na ud ud u harzase dAtavA u</s>, <ls>Kāś.</ls> on <ls>Pāṇ.</ls>)

748642 old <hom>1.</hom> <s>za</s> ¦ the second of the three sibilants (it belongs to the cerebral class, and is sometimes substituted for <s>s</s>, and more rarely for <s>S</s>, and occasionally interchangeable with <s>K</s>; in sound it corresponds to <i>sh</i> in the English word <i>shun</i>; many roots which begin with <s>s</s> are written in the <s1 slp1="DAtu-pAWa">Dhātu-pāṭha</s1> with <s>z</s>, <ab>prob.</ab> to show that their initial <s>s</s> is liable to be cerebralized after certain prepositions).

864231 old ¦ tone in recitation &c. (either high or low), accent (of which there are three kinds, <s>udAtta</s>, <s>anudAtta</s> <ab>qq.vv.</ab>, and <s>svarita</s>, <ab>col.</ab>3), a note of the musical scale (of which seven [rarely six or eight] are enumerated, 1. <s>nizAda</s>; 2. <s>fzaBa</s>; 3. <s>gAnDAra</s>; 4. <s>zaqja</s>; 5. <s>maDyama</s>; 6. <s>DEvata</s>; 7. <s>paYcama</s> [described as resembling respectively the notes of an elephant, bull, goat, peacock, curlew or heron, horse, and <bio>Koil</bio> <pb n="1285,2"/>; and designated by their initial letters or syllables thus, <s>ni</s>; <s>f</s>; <s>ga</s>; <s>za</s>; <s>ma</s>; <s>Da</s>; <s>pa</s>], but the order is sometimes changed, <s>zadja</s> being placed first, and <s>nizAda</s> last), <ls>Prāt.</ls>; <ls>ŚrS.</ls>; <ls>Saṃgīt.</ls>; <ls>MBh.</ls> &c.<info lex="inh"/>
